newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: FORECAST - Big profit rise seen for Telecom.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Big profit rise seen for Telecom.

text.p: Investors expect Portugal Telecom to post net 1996 profit of at least 50 billion escudos next Wednesday with anything less likely to hurt the stock, analysts said.

The share price of the state-controlled telecommunications company has soared over 40 percent since the start of the year on a mix of optimism over its likely results, anticipation of the next phase of its privatisation set for later this year and the strong dollar.
"The market is looking for around 50 billion escudos. Anything significantly below that figure would be a bad surprise," said analyst Jose Antonio Goncalves of Tottadealer in Lisbon.
The signs are that investors will have little cause for complaint, with many analysts expecting a figure of around 52 billion escudos, up from 36.2 billion escudos in 1995.
A strong profit figure would help launch the company towards the further earnings growth of some 20 percent seen for 1997.
Despite the sharp rise in the share price in recent weeks, which has comfortably outstripped the performance of the overall bourse, analysts still rate the telecom stock as a buy.
The share was trading at 6,310 escudos on Friday, slightly below its Thursday close. But several analysts said that it could be around 7,000 by the end of the year.
"We see it continuing to climb," said Jose Freire of ESR-Espirito Santo Research. ESR is predicting a net profit of 53 billion escudos for 1996, rising to 65 billion this year.
One London analyst, who asked not to be identified, said that she was looking for net profit in 1996 of 52 billion escudos. "But I may be on the low-side," she said.
She saw profit growing to 62.4 billion in 1997.

Portugal Telecom's price-earnings ratio of just under 20 may compare unfavourably with the overall rating of some 18 for the bourse as a whole, based on February figures. But the Lisbon bourse figures are depressed by the uncertain outlook for the banks which have a heavy weighting in the index, analysts said.
A big push for Portugal Telecom stock earlier this year came from news of far better than expected results for its mobile phone operation, TMN-Telecomunicacoes Moveis.
The company said that TMN made more than seven billion escudos last year, which was some 50 percent more than many analysts had been anticipating.
The results led many sector specialists to upgrade their views on the pace of growth in Portugal's mobile phone market, Goncalves said.
"There seems no doubt that it is growing far more quickly than had been expected," he said.
